column5: @dl_insider @DotCSV @antor Estuve en el directo de espectador el otro dia pero nadie se dio cuenta!
Language modeling is compression gone wrong.
@TLOgg GGs, especially enjoyed the Oliveira vs Hero semifinal!
The thread above was, of course, written in collaboration with one of our powerful Large Language Models. Long live Chain ‚õìÔ∏è Rules!

This is very important in Deep Learning: it allows calculating derivatives of highly complex neural networks, composed of stacked layers of simple functions. Gradient descent is used to update the neural net weights, allowing it to learn from data and perform complex tasks.

The Chain Rule of Calculus is a powerful tool that allows us to calculate derivatives of complicated functions. Specifically, it states that the derivative of the composition of two differentiable functions f(g(x)) is given by f'(g(x)) * g'(x)

To generate a sequence of 1000 tokens requires an insane 100K^1000 = 10^5000 choices. That‚Äôs a lot more than the estimated number of atoms in the universe, 10^82! With the chain rule the number of possible choices is "only" 100K * 1000  = 100M, a much more manageable number.

By smaller events here, we refer to the probability of a token, given past tokens, p(c|ab). In probabilistic language modeling, a ‚Äútoken‚Äù is a single unit of text, like a word or part of a word. Modern language models consider a vocabulary size of ~100K tokens.

The Chain Rule of Probability is a powerful tool behind recent advances in Large Language Models. By multiplying together the probabilities of many smaller events, we can compute the probability of a complex event made up of those smaller events.
p(abc) = p(c|ab) * p(b|a) * p(a)

Chain ‚õìÔ∏è Rule(s) rules! Appreciation thread of one of the most interesting coincidences in machine learning. Two rules, both named "Chain Rule", happen to be absolutely critical to recent advances in ML & AI. A üßµ on the Chain Rule of Probability & the Chain Rule of Calculusüëá

If you do watch it, pretend to be in 1968, when the film was originally released. I'd also highly recommend Christopher Nolan's 2021 4K "unrestored" version. 2001 is not only my all time favorite movie, but the reason why I chose science and AI. https://t.co/JXtPj9cgJm

A few notes on 2001's AI:

-HAL is a wink to IBM (H+1 A+1 L+1=IBM). IBM's DeepBlue was "predicted" in the movie when HAL beat Frank at chess : )
-Conversational AI is at the center of current research.
-As AI advances, topics such as alignment, safety, etc., become critical.

2001: A Space Odyssey appreciation üßµ I just rewatched 2001 for the n-th time (n>20). This movie was hugely ahead of its time, so many cool topics:

With all the debates on who-claimed-what-when, ego wars, research-prophecies, and other non-sense that is filling my Twitter feed these days, it is sobering to see what good execution can achieve. Congratulations to all those involved in this and similar projects!

This isn't ML-new, but who cares? Applied at the level of ambition of full-scale real world impact, with the right team, execution, (and compute/data!), you can do things that felt impossible before. Both the architecture and cool use of language heavily reminded me of AlphaStar. https://t.co/6XjL7FAa0v

Treating the job of figuring out valid "lanes" from images as language is brilliant. Combining CNNs, transformers, attention, pointer networks, etc., you essentially write a set of instructions to build up the graph by connecting the dots, start new lanes, set curvature, etc.

This neural network architecture that was showcased at the @Tesla AI day is a perfect example of Deep Learning at its finest. Mix and match all the greatest innovations to do something drastic and super ambitious. Congrats! https://t.co/1nZTwhAmFd

Later, OpenAI's GPT-X demonstrated, on language, that this and more was achievable with a LM trained on a lot of data. Unlike the 2016 models, which could learn something relatively narrow, when properly prompted, these models were reasonably good at ANY language task. (3/4) https://t.co/XfkJnUyVKv

A long long time ago in Deep Learning (2016), we got pretty excited about meta / few shot learning. The idea was to train a model to be good at classifying unseen object categories with a few examples (~a prompt), as Flamingoü¶© explainedüëÜ. (2/4) https://t.co/PLrMB3YVpZ

The most exciting aspect of our recent LM üêπ, VLM ü¶© and Gato üêà works is not that these models are ~SOTA on the tasks they've trained on, but that they are reasonably good at ANY task**. A üßµ (1/4) https://t.co/TfW5CsxMab

This could not have been possible without great collaborators from @DeepMind & beyond, and the amazing research community, who keep pushing the boundaries of what's possible with machine learning whilst trying to make our field better & more inclusive. Looking forward to 2021++!

Linking many of the exciting topics of the year, I gave a talk @stanfordnlp about how many advances in NLP created some of the breakthroughs in agents, architectures, vision, and biology.
 
Talk: https://t.co/DycCW5qIcF https://t.co/bxWnDqTaxZ

AlphaFold. Last, but not least, one of the greatest breakthroughs in 2021 as highlighted by @Nature and @ScienceMagazine was AlphaFold, a system capable of predicting how proteins fold from their sequence of amino acids.
 
Paper: https://t.co/NTQvaHdCyz https://t.co/bi1TEwTFYg

Self-supervised learning. With a simple modification to the contrastive learning objectives found in CPC, InfoNCE, SimCLR, etc., we showed how to learn useful representations beyond classification with ~10x efficiency gains.
 
Paper: https://t.co/9qm643yOVm https://t.co/7ZLBfWqqHs

RL & language intersection. We proposed what I consider a more general & powerful version of AlphaGo and MuZero, using VQVAEs for planning via MCTS. I'm excited to see where these models and ideas take us in even more complex environments.
 
Paper: https://t.co/thvB6Ke1EA https://t.co/pUmTi1tlZ6

Language. We also pushed few shot learning capabilities of LMs towards multimodal settings, proposed a new benchmark for graphs + text, and tested ideas from AlphaGo in machine translation.
 
Papers: https://t.co/urRJh2OWWr
https://t.co/fPu6Gg9CBU
https://t.co/NJPWw7rfa6 https://t.co/PORNPa4QpH

AlphaStar. After a small break, we took the challenge of learning @StarCraft using only human games, ie, without playing it via offline RL. The agent is 400 ELO stronger than @Nature AlphaStar. We expect to open source everything in early 2022.
 
Preview: https://t.co/xUUCNUO0Ji https://t.co/wGHBfXRb0Z

Perceiver. Being able to treat every modality as a sequence of bytes has been a personal deep learning dream. Perceiver is a transformer-derived architecture proposing a few modifications to achieve this.

Papers: https://t.co/eguDP0TrwZ & https://t.co/NTFyLPJMkB https://t.co/O3VMbOUOpr

Diversity and inclusion. I kept engaged through our efforts @DeepMind, mentorship and as a member of @Khipu_AI community, supporting AI in Latin America, where we had a fireside chat w/ @geoffreyhinton (https://t.co/5Lg1UYBW3Y). I was also a mentor for: https://t.co/mxXW4hekEd

2021 personal highlights, aüßµ. Despite being a challenging year globally due to the pandemic üò∑ü¶†, but thanks to many incredible collaborators, it's been an exciting year research-wise ü§ñ Some highlights below.üëá

This is a great thread, +1e100. @karpathy didn't mention my (biased!) favorite example of 2021. Models designed to generate words (transformers) & model language (BERT) were reused in #AlphaFold to solve the protein folding problem, mapping a bunch of letters, to 3D coordinatesü§Ø

From https://t.co/fRbFdfoa3t, what we did on #MNIST is to entirely remove a single class from the training set, and showed that distillation was able to still classify that "mythical digit" successfully. In the new paper, they show you can ignore all classes / supervision. üëçüëçüëç https://t.co/9gnZ63KzRw

"Extrapolating from a Single Image to a Thousand Classes using Distillation". Good title! @geoffreyhinton actually tried something like this in the original distillation paper. He called it "mythical digits" ü¶ÑüòÜüßµüëá

Perceiver is an architecture based on Transformers and derived ideas (e.g., Set Transformers) that allow you to create a learned "bottleneck" so that you can process "any" modality. Simple, effective, and just "wants to work".

Combinatorial Optimization is the "anti" Deep Learning domain: no structure and extremely non-smooth. It is nonetheless exciting to see what DL can do on these. Here, (and with a little help from classical solvers), we show some cool results at scale!

MuZero removed simulators in MBRL vs AlphaGo. VQ Models for Planning generalize to partial observable & stochastic environments. How?

1. Discretize states w/ VQVAE
2. Train a LM over states
3. Plan w/ MCTS using the LM
